Row.Text: This building represents an active Mandate gained from capturing a Capital or City-State.
Production bonus from stationed Lönchen based on religious buildings.
Faith and Science stolen by Lönchen in foreign territory.
Temporary movement bonus for units trained with a stationed Lönchen.

Trimalo Triteng, also known as Jema Trimalo, was one of the most influential female rulers in Tibetan history, and the only one to rule over all Tibet. As regent and de facto ruler during a crucial period of the Tibetan Empire's expansion, she demonstrated exceptional military and administrative acumen. Her reign saw the restoration of royal authority after overthrowing the powerful Gar clan that had dominated the empire for decades, establishing Tibet as a dominant power in Central Asia.

Under Trimalo's leadership, the Tibetan Empire successfully overthrew the powerful Gar clan that had monopolized political and military power for generations, restoring authority to the royal family. Her armies subdued numerous city-states along the Silk Road, extracting tribute and establishing Tibetan hegemony over crucial trade routes. These victories brought immense wealth and prestige to the empire, earning her the title "Sovereign Lady of the Many."

Trimalo revolutionized the Tibetan administrative system by appointing Lönchen (Great Ministers) to govern conquered territories. These officials, drawn from various noble families, ensured efficient tax collection and maintained order across the vast empire. The integration of religious authority with temporal power became a hallmark of Tibetan governance that would persist for centuries.

Despite her military focus, Trimalo was a patron of Buddhism. She commissioned the construction of numerous Tsuklakhang (temples) throughout the empire, which served not only as religious centers but also as fortresses and administrative hubs. These temples formed a strong foundation for the success of Buddhism as an adminstrative insitution for later rulers of the empire.

Trimalo Triteng's reign marked the zenith of Tibetan imperial power. Her combination of military conquest, administrative innovation, and religious patronage created a model of governance that influenced Central Asian politics for generations. Though the empire would eventually fragment, her legacy as Tibet's greatest female ruler remains unchallenged, inspiring future generations to remember the time when Tibet stood as equal to the greatest empires of Asia.

Glory to you, Trimalo Triteng—Sovereign Lady of the Dro clan—whose iron will steadied the throne and restored the royal line! When the great lords of the Gar overshadowed the crown, you broke their power, recalled the armies to loyal command, and set ministers over provinces so that edicts would run swifter than intrigue. Caravans once more bowed at the high passes as tolls were levied and safe-conduct granted; the Silk Road bent to Tibetan order, and distant courts learned to reckon with the red-cheeked ones. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] By your decree, sacred houses were repaired and royal sanctuaries renewed, that the favor of the gods and Dharma might stand beside the might of the state. Watchtowers rose on wind-scoured ridges, way stations dotted the trade roads, and the drums of the frontier answered to the bells of the temples. You bound chiefs and captains by oath, set law above faction, and turned a highland kingdom into a continent-spanning empire through discipline, tribute, and shrewd appointment. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE] Now, mighty empress, your people call upon your strength once more. Will you win the hearts of the clans and forge anew the mandate of heaven? Can you unite martial power with sacred authority, that snow-lion banners guard the passes while shrines keep the covenant of the realm? Can you build a civilization to stand the test of time?
Even empires built on divine mandate must eventually fall... but our spirit remains unconquered.
Friendship is not a shield against betrayal. I see your true intentions.
You dare attack the Sovereign Lady? Prepare to be crushed beneath the weight of my empire.
Your declaration of war is a grave mistake. My armies will show you no mercy.
Your expansion threatens the balance of power. Tread carefully, or Tibet will respond.
Welcome. I am Trimalo Triteng, Empress Regent of Tibet. Will you honor my sons or challenge my rule?
Your presence is unwelcome. Do not mistake my patience for weakness.
We meet on equal ground. Let us see if you are worthy of respect.
Greetings. May our dealings be honorable and beneficial.
Your military actions have not gone unnoticed. Tibet will defend its interests fiercely.
Let us discuss the exchange of luxuries. Prosperity benefits those who cooperate.
Open borders may serve us both, but do not abuse my trust.
Your attempts to buy land near my cities are provocative. Cease, or face consequences.
State your request. I will judge its merit.
Denounce me if you wish, but know that Tibet stands strong against all slander.
It is too soon for declarations of friendship. Prove your worth first.
Peace cannot be rushed. Time will reveal your intentions.
Your actions demand a response. I denounce your conduct before all.
Tibet is open to friendship, if you prove yourself honorable.

Each time you capture a Capital or City-State, gain a Mandate (max 3). Each Mandate grants +10%[ICON_PRODUCTION]Unit Production empire-wide and +10[ICON_PEACE]Faith. You can expend a Mandate to grant +25[ICON_INFLUENCE]Influence to all met City-States and Hurry Production in the Capital.

Unique Great General replacement. Can be stationed in Cities to provide +10%[ICON_PRODUCTION]Production for each Religious Building. While stationed in another Civilization's territory, provides a small portion of their[ICON_PEACE]Faith and[ICON_RESEARCH]Science. Can be Purged to increase Mandate count if at 0.

The Lönchen is a unique Great General replacement for the Tibetan Empire. Unlike regular Great Generals, Lönchen can be stationed in cities to boost production based on religious buildings, or placed in foreign territory to steal Faith and Science. If you have no Mandates, you can sacrifice a Lönchen to gain one. Use them strategically to maximize your empire's production or gather intelligence from rivals.

The Lönchen were the highest ministers in the Tibetan Empire, serving as both military commanders and civil administrators. These great ministers governed provinces, led armies, and managed the complex relationships between the imperial court and Buddhist monasteries. Their dual role as temporal and spiritual authorities made them indispensable to the functioning of the empire.

Units trained in this City receive a Zeal promotion: +10%[ICON_STRENGTH]CS on Rough Terrain per Mandate. If a Lönchen is stationed in the City, those Units also start with +1[ICON_MOVES]Movement for 5 turns.

The Tsuklakhang is a unique Temple replacement for the Tibetan Empire. It provides the same Faith as a Temple but also grants the Zeal promotion to units trained in the city, giving them combat bonuses on rough terrain based on your Mandate count. Station a Lönchen in the city to give new units temporary movement bonuses. Build Tsuklakhang in production cities to create powerful military units.

Tsuklakhang, meaning "House of Religious Teaching," were the great temple royal temples of the Tibetan Empire. These massive complexes served multiple functions: religious centers for Buddhist practice and administrative headquarters for regional governance. Their thick walls and strategic locations made them both spiritual sanctuaries and defensive strongholds.
Maximum Mandates reached! Cannot gain more.
[COLOR_POSITIVE_TEXT]Mandate Expended![ENDCOLOR] +{1_Influence} Influence with {2_Count} City-States, 25% Production in Capital. Mandates remaining: {3_Remaining}
Can only purge Lönchen when you have no Mandates!
Unit trained with Zeal and +1 Movement for {1_Turns} turns!
